Both operations were coordinated from Moscow; however, there was a shocking difference between their outcomes.<ref name="Palski2008">{{cite book | url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/download.php?s=1&id=16410 | title=Operacja Wisła: komunistyczna akcja represyjna, czy obrona konieczna Rzeczypospolitej? | publisher=Nasz Dziennik, [[Institute of National Remembrance]] | work=Dodatek historyczny IPN Nr. 5/2008 (12) | date=30 May 2008 | accessdate=12 July 2015 | author=Dr Zbigniew Palski | at=pp. 6–7 (3–4 in PDF) | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229100110/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/download.php?s=1&id=16410 | archivedate=29 December 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
While Operation Vistula was underway in south-western Poland, the Soviet NKVD deported over 114,000 mostly women and children from [[West Ukraine]] to [[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic|Kazakh SSR]] and Siberia during parallel Operation West.<ref name="Palski2008"/> Only 19,000 men were among the Soviet deportees,<ref name="Palski2008"/> most of them sent to coal mines and stone quarries in the north. None of the families deported by the NKVD received any farms or empty homes to live in. They were instantaneously forced into extreme poverty and hunger.<ref name="Palski2008"/> Dr Zbigniew Palski informs also that during Operation Vistula none of the three conditions of the [[United Nations Charter]] of 26 June 1945 about the possible struggle toward their own self-determination among the Polish deportees was broken at the time. Other international laws were already in effect.<ref name="Palski2008"/>

Snyder }} * {{cite book | first= Norman| last= Davies | title=God's Playground: A History of Poland, Vol. 1: The Origins to 1795 | publisher=Columbia University Press| year=2005 | isbn=0-231-12817-7 | authorlink= Norman Davies}} * Litwin Henryk, [https://www.msz.gov.pl/resource/49da65c5-9917-40de-b542-5c89751cacf6:JCR ''Central European Superpower''], ''BUM Magazine'', 2016. * [[Tomasz Kamusella]]. 2013. revision.text:
'''The Q Hall of Fame Canada''' is a national resource dedicated to house and commemorate the diverse history of the [[LGBT|lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender]] community in [[Canada]]. They honour those that have been human rights pioneers and document the accomplishments and lives of these amazing people. Headquartered in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], the Q Hall of Fame is an independently registered federal not for profit organization with the [[Minister of Industry (Canada)|Minister of Industry for Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corporations.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/cd-dgc.nsf/eng/cs04522.html|title=Letters Patent (CCA)|publisher=Industry Canada|date=2010|accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref>
The Q Hall of Fame Canada was created in 2009 by founder and chair, Paul Therien. It was in response to what he perceived to be a lack of recognition for people who have greatly impacted the lives of LGBTQ Canadians through their dedication to human rights.<ref name="WFP">{{cite news|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/canada/trudeau-named-to-queer-hall-of-fame-59930437.html|title=Trudeau named to Queer Hall of Fame|last=Theodore|first=Terri|date=20 September 2009|publisher=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]|accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref> It is an independent entity and is not associated directly with [[Qmunity]] in governance or management. At the inaugural induction ceremony for the Q Hall of Fame, known as Q Ball,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trendhunter.com/trends/alternative-awards-q-ball|title=Alternative Lifestyle Awards|publisher=Trendhunter Social|accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref> Qmunity was the "selected beneficiary" of the 2009 proceeds and "a possible future home of the hall's memorabilia", however a recent shift in the mandate of the Hall of Fame has amended that.<ref name="Perelle, 2009-09-24">{{cite news |title=QBall's lessons |first=Robin |last=Perelle |url=http://www.xtra.ca/public/Vancouver/QBalls_lessons-7554.aspx |newspaper=[[Xtra!]] |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref>
Inductees for the Q Hall of Fame are selected through a public nomination process. Nominees are usually members of the LGBT community themselves, although heterosexual allies who have played prominent roles in the protection or advancement of LGBT equality rights in Canada — such as former Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]] — may also be honoured.
At the 2009 induction ceremony, entertainer Robert Kaiser (also known as Joan-E) was the first inductee into the Hall of Fame,<ref name="Perelle, 2009-09-24"/> and he was followed by Olympic [[gold medal]]ist [[Mark Tewksbury]], head of the Canadian Drag Court [[International Court System|Ted Northe]], author and bookseller [[Janine Fuller]]<ref name="WFP" /> and former [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Pierre Trudeau]], for his role in [[decriminalization|decriminalising]] [[homosexuality]] in Canada.<ref>{{cite news |title=Pierre Trudeau inducted into Queer Hall of Fame |first=Kevin |last=Jess |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/279496 |newspaper=DigitalJournal.com |date=20 September 2009 |accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref>
Held every two years, Q Ball was held in [[Vancouver]] in 2009, and again in 2011. In 2013 Q Ball will be held in [[Toronto]], in keeping with the mandate that the event be accessible to all Canadians. All nominations are reviewed by an independent selection committee which comprises community members from across Canada. The identities of the members of the selection committee are kept strictly confidential to ensure that they remain as unbiased as possible when reviewing the nominations.
==Inductees== ===2009=== *[[Janine Fuller]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/janine-fuller/ Janine Fuller] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221817/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/janine-fuller/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *Robert Kaiser<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/joan-e-robert-kaiser/ Robert Kaiser] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704220329/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/joan-e-robert-kaiser/ |date=July 4, 2012 }}</ref> *[[International Court System|Ted Northe]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/ted-northe/ ted northe] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815131826/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/ted-northe/ |date=August 15, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Mark Tewksbury]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/mark-tewksbury/ Mark Tewksbury] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221806/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/mark-tewksbury/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Pierre Trudeau]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/pierre-elliot-trudeau/ Pierre Eliott Trudeau] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819091413/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/pierre-elliot-trudeau/ |date=August 19, 2014 }}</ref>
===2011=== *Rick Bébout<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/rick-bebout-1950-%e2%80%93-2010/ Rick Bebout] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221828/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/rick-bebout-1950-%e2%80%93-2010/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *Karen Busby<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/prof-karen-busby/ Karen Busby] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221835/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/prof-karen-busby/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *Jeremy Dias<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/jeremy-dias/ Jeremy Dias] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423222150/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/jeremy-dias/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *Dogwood Monarchist Society<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/dogwood-monarchist-society/ Dogwood Monarchist Society] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120724071327/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/dogwood-monarchist-society/ |date=July 24, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Gens Hellquist]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/gens-hellquist/ Gens Hellquist] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221729/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/gens-hellquist/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *[[k.d. lang]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/k-d-lang/ k.d. lang] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423222208/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/k-d-lang/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *Kevin Dale McKeown<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/kevin-dale-mckeown/ Kevin Dale McKeown] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120724071314/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/kevin-dale-mckeown/ |date=July 24, 2012 }}</ref> *NiQ<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/niq/ NiQ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221949/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/niq/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Cynthia Petersen]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/cynthia-petersen/ Cynthia Petersen] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423221905/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/cynthia-petersen/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Mirha-Soleil Ross]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/mihra-soleil-ross/ Mirha-Soleil Ross] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328015538/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/mihra-soleil-ross/ |date=March 28, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Delwin Vriend]]<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/delwin-vriend/ Delwin Vriend] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423222031/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/delwin-vriend/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref> *Garth Wiens<ref>[http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/garth-wiens/ Garth Wiens] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423222433/http://qhalloffame.ca/inductees/garth-wiens/ |date=April 23, 2012 }}</ref>
===2013=== *[[Jack Layton]] *[[Marie Robertson (activist)|Marie Robertson]] *[[Jane Rule]] *Barbara Snelgrove<ref>{{cite web|last1=Takeuchi|first1=Craig|title=Q Hall of Fame 2013 inductees include Vancouver's Barb Snelgrove|url=https://www.straight.com/life/406886/q-hall-fame-2013-inductees-include-vancouvers-barb-snelgrove|website=The Georgia Straight|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> *Darrin Hagen *[[Brent Hawkes|Rev. page.title: Resident Governor of the Tower of London and Keeper of the Jewel House

revision.text:
The '''Resident Governor of the Tower of London and Keeper of the Jewel House''' is responsible for the day-to-day running of the [[Tower of London]].
The [[Constable of the Tower]] is the most senior appointment at the Tower of London. Under the [[Queen's Regulations]] for the Army, the office of constable is conferred on a field marshal or retired general officer for a five-year term. At the conclusion of the Constable's installation ceremony, the [[Lord Chamberlain]] symbolically hands the palace over to the Constable. He in turn entrusts it to the Resident Governor.
The offices of ''Resident Governor of the Tower of London'' and ''[[Master of the Jewel Office|Keeper of the Jewel House]]'' were amalgamated in 1967.<ref name="HolmesSitwell1972">{{cite book|author1=Martin Holmes|author2=Major-General H. D. W. Sitwell|title=The English Regalia: Rheir History, Custody and Display|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HJ8sAQAAIAAJ|year=1972|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office|isbn=978-0-1167-0407-8|page=v|quote=It would perhaps be appropriate at this stage to mention that the in 1967 the Jewel House in the Tower and the staff was increased and reorganised. The Officer-in-Charge is now also the Resident Governor - the two posts having been merged under the title of Resident Governor and Keeper of the Jewel House. He is an officer of the Royal House hold and is responsible, only as far a custody of the Crown Jewels in the Tower is concerned, to the Lord Chamberlain of the Royal Household who has had control of the Jewel House since 1782.}}</ref>
==List of combined office holders== List of combined office holders:
*1967: [[Colonel]] Sir Thomas Pierce [[Butler baronets|Butler]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/45323/page/2277/data.pdf|title=State Intelligence|newspaper=The London Gazette|date=16 March 1971}}</ref> *1971: [[Major-General]] Sir Digby Raeburn<ref>{{cite news|title=Obituary, Major-General Sir Digby Raeburn KCVO|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1365014/Major-General-Sir-Digby-Raeburn.html|work=The Telegraph|date=12 Dec 2001}}</ref> *1979: Major-General Giles Mills<ref>{{cite news|title=Obituary, Major General Giles Mills|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/military-obituaries/army-obituaries/8834931/Major-General-Giles-Mills.html|work=The Telegraph|date=18 Oct 2011}}</ref> *1984: Major-General Andrew Patrick Withy MacLellan<ref name="gazette"/> *1989: Major-General Christopher Tyler<ref name="gazette">{{cite news|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/51821/page/8629/data.pdf|newspaper=The London Gazette|date=25 July 1989|title=State Intelligence}}</ref> *1994: Major-General Geoffrey Field<ref name="ImpeyAshbee2008">{{cite book|author1=Edward Impey|author1-link=Edward Impey|author2=Jeremy Ashbee|title=The White Tower|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jGbqAAAAMAAJ|year=2008|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-11293-1|page=x}}</ref> *2006: Major-General Keith Cima<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14405470|publisher=BBC News|date=4 August 2011|title=Ex-Tower of London boss Keith Cima: 'Drug used to frame me'}}</ref> *2011: Colonel Richard Harrold
==See also== *[[Jewel House]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{More citations needed|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox political party |country=Turkey |name = Rights and Equality Party |native_name = Hak ve Eşitlik Partisi |logo = Hak ve Eşitlik Partisi (logo).jpg |logo_size = 150px |colorcode = red |foundation = {{start date|2008|9|4|df=y}} |leader = [[Yücel Savaş]] |founder = [[Osman Pamukoğlu]] |membership = 589 {{cite web|url=http://www.yargitaycb.gov.tr/sayfa/faaliyette-olan-siyasi-partiler/1136 |title=Hak Ve Eşitlik Partisi |publisher=Yargitaycb.gov.tr |date=2017-04-21|language=tr}} |membership_year = 2017 |ideology = [[Turkish nationalism]]
[[Populism]]
[[Kemalism]] |position = [[Third position]] |colours = Red, white, black |headquarters = Mareşal Fevzi Çakmak Cad. No:37 Beşevler, [[Ankara]] |website = [http://www.hakveesitlik.org.tr/ Official Site] }} The '''Rights and Equality Party''' ({{lang-tr|Hak ve Eşitlik Partisi}}, '''HEPAR''') is a political party in [[Turkey]], founded on 4 September 2008 by [[Osman Pamukoğlu]], a former army general known for his military successes against the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] in the 1990s during the [[Turkey–PKK conflict]].[http://www.hakveesitlik.org.tr/osman-pamukoglu-kimdir.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229025604/http://www.hakveesitlik.org.tr/osman-pamukoglu-kimdir.html |date=December 29, 2010 }} The party's main manifest is the setting sovereignty, own based economical development and peace for Turkish citizens. The party has 8,273 members as of 2014.[http://www.hakveesitlik.org.tr/dosya/siyasal_ve_toplumsal_ilkelerimiz.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229015024/http://www.hakveesitlik.org.tr/dosya/siyasal_ve_toplumsal_ilkelerimiz.pdf |date=December 29, 2010 }} The party claims their ideology as being neither on the right nor left, above all with populist, nationalist aiming social justice for Turkish citizens. The party chairman Osman Pamukoğlu often mentions [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]]'s quote as "Our target is being a merged society with no classes and privileges." The party has gained 121,814 votes during the [[Turkish general election, 2011|2011 elections]], comprising 0.28% of the votes. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.hakveesitlik.org.tr/ Rights and Equality Party] {{tr icon}} {{Turkish nationalism}} {{Turkish political parties}} [[Category:2008 establishments in Turkey]] [[Category:Kemalist political parties]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in Turkey]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2008]] [[Category:Political parties in Turkey]] [[Category:Populist parties]] [[Category:Third Position]] [[Category:Turkish nationalist organizations]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = S. I. Hayakawa |image = SIHayakawa.jpg |jr/sr = United States Senator |state = [[California]] |term_start = January 2, 1977 |term_end = January 3, 1983 |predecessor = [[John V. Tunney]] |successor = [[Pete Wilson]] |title1 = President of
[[San Francisco State University]] |order1 = 9th |term_start1 = November 26, 1968 |term_end1 = July 10, 1973 |predecessor1 = Robert Smith |successor1 = Paul Romberg |birth_name = Samuel Ichiye Hayakawa |birth_date = {{birth date|1906|07|18}} |birth_place = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada |death_date = {{death date and age|1992|2|27|1906|7|18}} |death_place = [[Greenbrae, California|Greenbrae]], [[California]], U.S. |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (before 1973)
[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (1973–1992) |spouse = Margedant Peters |children = 3 |education = [[University of Manitoba]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[McGill University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[University of Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin, Madison]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) |module = {{Infobox academic | child=yes | alma_mater = | thesis_title = Oliver Wendell Holmes: Physician, poet, essayist | thesis_url = https://search.proquest.com/docview/301811415/ | thesis_year = 1935 | school_tradition = | doctoral_advisor = . | academic_advisors = | influences = | era = | discipline = English | sub_discipline = Linguistics, semantics | workplaces = {{ublist|[[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]|[[Armour Institute of Technology]]|[[University of Chicago]]|[[San Francisco State College]]}} | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | main_interests = | notable_works = [[Language in Thought and Action]] | notable_ideas = | influenced = }} }} '''Samuel Ichiye Hayakawa''' (July 18, 1906 – February 27, 1992) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]]-born American academic and politician of [[Japanese Americans|Japanese]] ancestry. A professor of [[English studies|English]], he served as president of [[San Francisco State University]],{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NM8RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VO0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3914%2C5372406 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=''(Los Angeles Times)'' |title=Hayakawa will retire |date=October 13, 1972 |page=1}} and then as [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] from [[California]] from 1977 to 1983.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zk9WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jOsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6777%2C6007646 |work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |agency=''(Los Angeles Times)'' |title=S.I. Hayakawa, 85, dies; challenged '60s radicals |date=February 28, 1992 |page=7A}} == Early life and education == Born in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Hayakawa was educated in the public schools of [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], and [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], and received an undergraduate degree from the [[University of Manitoba]] in 1927 and graduate degrees in English from [[McGill University]] in 1928 and the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] in 1935.{{cite thesis |url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/301811415/ |title=Oliver Wendell Holmes: Physician, poet, essayist |date=1935 |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] |type=Ph.D. |last=Hayakawa |first=Samuel I. |via=[[ProQuest]] |subscription=yes |oclc=51566055}} ==Academic career== Professionally, Hayakawa was a [[linguistics|linguist]], psychologist, [[semantics|semanticist]], teacher, and writer. He served as an instructor at the [[University of Wisconsin]] from 1936 to 1939 and at the Armour Institute of Technology (now [[Illinois Institute of Technology]]) from 1939 to 1948. His first book on semantics, ''[[Language in Thought and Action]]'', was published in 1949 as an expansion of the earlier work, ''Language in Action'', written since 1938 and published in 1941 to be a [[Book-of-the-Month Club]] selection. It is currently in its fifth edition and has greatly helped to popularize [[Alfred Korzybski]]'s [[general semantics]] and semantics in general, while semantics or theory of meaning was overwhelmed{{when|date=April 2018}} by [[mysticism]], [[propagandism]] and even [[scientism]].{{clarify|date=March 2017}} In the preface, Hayakawa cautioned: {{quote|The original version of this book, ''Language in Action'', published in 1941, was in many respects a response to the dangers of propaganda, especially as exemplified in Adolf Hitler's success in persuading millions to share his maniacal and destructive views. It was the writer's conviction then, as it remains now, that everyone needs to have a habitually critical attitude towards language—his own as well as that of others—both for the sake of his personal well being and for his adequate functioning as a citizen. Hitler is gone, but if the majority of our fellow citizens are more susceptible to the slogans of fear and race hatred than to those of peaceful accommodation and mutual respect among human beings, our political liberties remain at the mercy of any eloquent and unscrupulous demagogue.}} In addition to such motivation, he acknowledged his debt as follows: {{quote|My deepest debt in this book is to the General Semantics ('non-Aristotelian system') of Alfred Korzybski. I have also drawn heavily upon the works of other contributors to semantic thought: especially C. K. Ogden and I. A. Richards, Thorstein Veblen, Edward Sapir, Leonard Bloomfield, Karl R. Popper, Thurman Arnold, Jerome Frank, Jean Piaget, Charles Morris, Wendell Johnson, Irving J. Lee, Ernst Cassirer, Anatol Rapoport, Stuart Chase. I am also deeply indebted to the writings of numerous psychologists and psychiatrists with one or another of the dynamic points of view inspired by Sigmund Freud: Karl Menninger, Trigant Burrow, Carl Rogers, Kurt Lewin, N. R. F. Maier, Jurgen Ruesch, Gregory Bateson, Rudolf Dreikurs, Milton Rokeach. I have also found extremely helpful the writings of cultural anthropologists, especially those of Benjamin Lee Whorf, Ruth Benedict, Clyde Kluckhohn, Leslie A. White, Margaret Mead, Weston La Barre.}} He was a lecturer at the [[University of Chicago]] from 1950 to 1955. During this time he presented a talk at the 1954 Conference of '''Activity Vector Analysts'''{{cite web |url=http://www.webava.com/home.asp |title=WebAVA |accessdate=February 8, 2015}} at [[Lake George, New York|Lake George]], [[New York (state)|New York]], in which he discussed a theory of personality from the semantic point of view. This was later published as ''The Semantic Barrier''. This was a definitive lecture as it discussed the [[Darwinism]] of the "survival of self" as contrasted with the "survival of [[self-concept]]". His ideas on general semantics influenced [[A. E. van Vogt]]'s Null-A novels, ''[[The World of Null-A]]'' and ''[[The Pawns of Null-A]]''. Van Vogt in ''The World of Null-A'' (i.e., non-Aristotelian) makes Hayakawa a character, introducing him as: "Professor Hayakawa is today's Mr. Null-A himself, the elected head of the International Society for General Semantics."{{cite book|author=Alfred Elton Van Vogt|title=The World of Null-A|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5WtbAAAAMAAJ|year=1977|publisher=Berkley Books|location=New York|page=11|isbn=9780425054543}} Hayakawa was an English professor at [[San Francisco State University|San Francisco State College]] (now San Francisco State University) from 1955 to 1968. In the early 1960s, he helped organize the ''Anti Digit Dialing League'', a San Francisco group that opposed the introduction of all-digit [[telephone exchange names]]. Among the students he trained were commune leader [[Stephen Gaskin]] and author [[Gerald Haslam]]. He was named acting president of San Francisco State College (now [[San Francisco State University]]) on November 26, 1968, when [[Ronald Reagan]] was [[governor of California]] and [[Joseph Alioto]] was [[mayor of San Francisco]].{{cite web|url=http://jpllweb.sfsu.edu/exhibits/strike/case3-text.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160831043627/http://jpllweb.sfsu.edu/exhibits/strike/case3-text.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 31, 2016|title=Case 3: Prelude / Demands|work=On Strike! Shut it Down! (Exhibit 1999)|publisher=Leonard Library, San Francisco State University|accessdate=June 24, 2017}} On July 9, 1969, the [[California State University|California State Colleges]] Board of Trustees appointed Hayakawa the ninth president of San Francisco State.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MAJGPGqOJ8oC&pg=PA187&lpg=PA187&dq=%22Samuel+i+hayakawa%22+1973&source=bl&ots=HW6pelQSym&sig=YPUVYW2fhfA2az8te-uaI-ZOQII&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjbpK7EtNfUAhVJ_WMKHRjEAZU4ChDoAQgsMAE#v=onepage&q=%22Samuel%20i%20hayakawa%22%201973&f=false|title=Reagan: A Life In Letters|page=187|publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=2004|isbn=0743219678}} Hayakawa retired on July 10, 1973.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1973/7/17/san-francisco-state-faculty-protests-selection/|title=San Francisco State Faculty Protests Selection of Hayakawa's Successor|author=Bittlingmayer, George|work=The Harvard Crimson|date=July 17, 1973|accessdate=June 24, 2017}} Hayakawa wrote a column for the [[Register and Tribune Syndicate]] from 1970 to 1976. In 1973, Hayakawa changed his political affiliation from the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and became president emeritus at what became San Francisco State University.{{cite web|url=http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt3199r7x0/admin/|title=Guide to the Samuel I. Hayakawa Papers|publisher=Online Archive of California|accessdate=June 24, 2017}} ===Student strike at San Francisco State College=== In 1968–69, there was a bitter student and [[Black Panthers]] strike at San Francisco State University in order to establish an [[ethnic studies]] program. It was a major news event at the time and chapter in the radical history of the [[United States]] and the Bay Area. The strike was led by the [[Third World Liberation Front]] supported by [[Students for a Democratic Society (1960 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]], the [[Black Panthers]] and the countercultural community. It proposed fifteen "non-negotiable demands", including a [[Black Studies]] department chaired by sociologist [[Nathan Hare]] independent of the university administration and open admission to all black students to "put an end to racism", and the unconditional, immediate end to the [[War in Vietnam]] and the university's involvement. It was threatened that if these demands were not immediately and completely satisfied the entire campus was to be forcibly shut down.{{cite book|last=Hayward|first=Steven|title=The Age of Reagan, Volume I|publisher=Crown Forum|page=446}} Hayakawa became popular with conservative voters in this period after he pulled the wires out from the loud speakers on a protesters' van at an outdoor rally.{{cite news |author=James M. Fallows |authorlink=James Fallows |date=January 15, 1969 |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1969/1/15/song-of-hayakawa-pbibf-morris-abram/ |title=Song of Hayakawa |work=[[The Harvard Crimson]] |accessdate=February 8, 2015}}[http://time.com/time/magazine/printout/0,8816,901065,00.html Yaga.com]{{Dead link|date=May 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.library.sfsu.edu/about/collections/strike/choronology.html |publisher=Leonard Library |title=The San Francisco State College Strike Collection, Chronology of events |accessdate=February 8, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510140936/http://www.library.sfsu.edu/about/collections/strike/choronology.html |archivedate=May 10, 2015 |df= }} Hayakawa relented on December 6, 1968, and created the first-in-the-nation College of Ethnic Studies{{cite AV Media |title=Hayakawa & angry demonstrations, Part I |work=KQED News |date=December 6, 1968 |publisher=San Francisco Bay Area Television Archive |url=https://diva.sfsu.edu/collections/sfbatv/bundles/187205 |accessdate=February 8, 2015}} ==Political career== Hayakawa won an unexpected victory in the 1976 Republican senate primary over three better-known career politicians including HEW Secretary [[Robert Finch (American politician)|Robert Finch]], long-time Congressman [[Alphonso Bell]], and California Lt. Governor [[John L. Harmer]]. Much like [[Jimmy Carter]], Hayakawa touted himself as a political outsider. [[Image:1977 Hayakawa p15.jpg|thumb|160px|right|1977, ''Congressional Pictorial Directory'']] On the Democratic side, incumbent Senator [[John V. Tunney|John Tunney]] faced a surprisingly strong challenge from another political outsider, [[Tom Hayden]]. Hayden's extremely liberal candidacy forced Tunney to run more to the left in the primary, which hurt him in the general election. Nevertheless, Tunney was favored{{by whom|date=April 2018}} to easily win re-election. Comfortably ahead in the polls, Tunney did not aggressively campaign until the final weeks before the election. But Hayakawa's position as a political outsider was popular in the wake of the [[Watergate Scandal]]. In addition, Tunney had a high absenteeism rate while serving in the Senate and missed numerous votes. Hayakawa exploited this with a TV ad that showed an empty chair in the US Senate chamber. Hayakawa gradually closed the gap with Tunney, and ultimately defeated him by just over three percentage points. During his 1976 Senate campaign, he spoke about the proposal to transfer possession of the [[Panama Canal]] and [[Panama Canal Zone|Canal Zone]] from the United States to [[Panama]]. Hayakawa said, "We should keep the Panama Canal. After all, we stole it fair and square."{{cite web|url=http://www.anvari.org/fortune/Miscellaneous_Collections/416905_we-should-keep-the-panama-canal-after-all-we-stole-it-fair-and-square-s-i.html |title=We Should Keep The Panama Canal. After All, We Stole It Fair And Square. – S.I |publisher=Anvari.org |date= |accessdate=2014-08-17}} However, in 1978 he helped win Senate approval of the [[Torrijos–Carter Treaties]], which transferred control of the zone and canal to Panama.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-02-28/news/mn-2960_1_state-college/2 |title=Ex-Sen. Hayakawa Dies; Unpredictable Iconoclast ...|first= |last=staff |date=February 28, 1992|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} He also supported a bill that led to the creation of the [[Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians]], which examined the causes and effects of the [[Internment of Japanese Americans|incarceration of Japanese Americans]] during [[World War II]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=Robinson |first=Greg |url=http://encyclopedia.densho.org/S.I.%20Hayakawa/ |title=S.I. Hayakawa |publisher=Densho Encyclopedia |accessdate=August 13, 2014}} During his time in the U.S. Senate, Hayakawa was one of three [[Japanese American]]s in the chamber, the other two being [[Daniel Inouye]] and [[Spark Matsunaga]], both of [[Hawaii]]. He planned to run for reelection in 1982 but trailed other Republican candidates badly in early polls and was short on money. He dropped out of the race early in the year and was ultimately succeeded by Republican [[San Diego]] [[Mayor of San Diego|mayor]] [[Pete Wilson]]. Hayakawa founded the political lobbying organization [[U.S. English (organization)|U.S. English]], which is dedicated to making the [[English language]] the [[official language]] of the United States.{{cite web|url=http://ccis.ucsd.edu/PUBLICATIONS/wrkg141.pdf |title=Language politics and policy in the United States: Implications for the immigration debate*, Working Paper 141 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061103095937/http://ccis.ucsd.edu/PUBLICATIONS/wrkg141.pdf |archivedate=November 3, 2006 }}{{confusing|date=November 2014}}{{cite book | title= Achieving the Impossible Dream: How Japanese Americans Obtained Redress | first1= Mitchell Takeshi | last1= Maki | first2= Harry H. L. | last2= Kitano | first3= Sarah Megan | last3= Berthold | publisher= University of Illinois | date= 1999 | isbn= 0-252-02458-3 | pages= 104–105}} Hayakawa, who lived in [[Chicago]] as a Canadian citizen during World War II and was thus not subject to confinement, argued that the [[internment of Japanese Americans]] "eventually worked to their advantage" and that Japanese Americans should not be paid for "fulfilling their obligations" to submit to [[Executive Order 9066]].Testimony of S.I. Hayakawa on Senate Bill 2116. Presented to Subcommittee on Appropriations, August 16, 1984. (Transcript available in [http://archive.densho.org/main.aspx Densho Digital Archive], courtesy of Cherry Kinoshita.) == Personal life == Hayakawa was a resident of [[Mill Valley, California|Mill Valley]], California, until his death in nearby [[Greenbrae, California|Greenbrae]], in 1992. He was also a member of the [[Bohemian Club]].{{citation needed|date= November 2014}} He had an abiding interest in [[traditional jazz]] and wrote extensively on that subject, including several erudite sets of album [[liner notes]]. Sometimes in his lectures on semantics, he was joined by the respected traditional [[jazz piano|jazz pianist]] [[Don Ewell]], whom Hayakawa employed to demonstrate various points in which he analyzed semantic and musical principles. Hayakawa was often favorite fodder for the news media reporters, every time he was found napping through important legislative voting. He was the nephew-in-law of [[Joseph Stalin]], in that his wife Margedant's brother [[William Wesley Peters]] was married to Stalin's daughter [[Svetlana Alliluyeva]]. https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1992/02/28/outspoken-us-senator-si-hayakawa-dies-at-85/761fdf45-6557-4b88-99fc-1a66d5628e43/ ==See also== *[[List of Asian Americans and Pacific Islands Americans in the United States Congress]] *[[List of United States Senators born outside the United States]] ==Bibliography== * Hayakawa, S. Originally published as ''Funk & Wagnalls Modern Guide to Synonyms and Related Words''. * Hayakawa, S. I. "Education Revisited". ''In The World Today'', edited by Phineas J. Sparer. [[Image:serkland.jpg|thumb|'''srklant''' on the [[Tillinge Runestone]] raised in memory of a [[Varangians|Varangian]] who did not return from Serkland, at the church of Tillinge in [[Uppland]], [[Sweden]].]]
In [[Old Norse]] sources, such as [[saga]]s and [[runestone]]s, '''Serkland''' (also ''Særkland'', ''Srklant'', ''Sirklant'', ''Serklat'', etc.) was the "land of the ''Serkir''", usually identified with the [[Saracens]].
The exact etymology is disputed. ''Serk''- may derive from "Saracen"; from ''sericum'', Latin for "silk", implying a connection with the [[Silk Road]]; from the Khazar fortress of [[Sarkel]]; or from ''serkr'', shirt or gown, i.e., "land of the gown-wearers". In all cases it refers to a land in the East. Originally, it referred to the land south of the [[Caspian Sea]], but it gradually expanded to cover all Islamic lands, including in Africa (and possibly even [[Muslim Sicily]]).<ref>Judith Jesch, ''Ships and Men in the Late Viking Age: The Vocabulary of Runic Inscriptions and Skaldic Verse'' (Boydell, 2001), p. 104ff.</ref><ref>Stefan Brink, "People and land in Early Scandinavia", in Ildar H. Garipzanov, Patrick Geary and Przemyslaw Urbanczyk (eds.), ''Franks, Northmen, and Slavs: Identities and State Formation in Early Medieval Europe'' (Brepols, 2008) p. 98.</ref>
Notably one of the [[Ingvar runestones]], the [[Ingvar runestones#Sö 179|Sö 179]], raised circa 1040 at [[Gripsholm Castle]], commemorates a [[Varangians|Varangian]] loss during an ill-fated raid in Serkland. The other remaining runestones that talk of Serkland are [[Ingvar runestones#Sö 131|Sö 131]], [[Ingvar runestones#Sö 279|Sö 279]], [[Ingvar runestones#Sö 281|Sö 281]], the [[Tillinge Runestone]] and probably the lost runestone [[Ingvar runestones#U 439|U 439]]. For a detailed account of such raids, see [[Caspian expeditions of the Rus']].
Several sagas mention Serkland: ''[[Ynglinga saga]]'', ''[[Sörla saga sterka]]'', ''[[Sörla þáttr]]'', ''[[Saga Sigurðar Jórsalafara]]'' and ''[[Hjálmþés saga ok Ölvis]]''. It is also mentioned by the 11th century [[skald]] [[Þórgils Fiskimaðr]],<ref>[http://skaldic.arts.usyd.edu.au/db.php?table=verses&id=4301 Þórgils fiskimaðr, Nordmand, 11 årh. (AI, 400-1, BI, 369).]</ref> and the 12th century skald [[Þórarinn Stuttfeldr]].<ref>[http://skaldic.arts.usyd.edu.au/db.php?table=verses&id=4627 Þórarinn stuttfeldr, Islandsk skjald, 12. årh. (AI, 489-92, BI, 461-4).]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Ancient Germanic culture}} * [[Garðaríki]] * {{slink|Names of Istanbul|Old Norse}} * [[Vinland]]

Stockholm 1963. * Carl L. Thunberg. [https://www.academia.edu/6173759/Sarkland_och_dess_kallmaterial ''Särkland och dess källmaterial'']. Gothenburg 2011.

{{Infobox museum | name = Shipley Art Gallery | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Shipley Art Gallery2.JPG | imagesize = 240 | caption = | alt = | map_type = United Kingdom Tyne and Wear | map_caption = [[File:Red pog.svg|8px]] Shipley Art Gallery shown within Tyne and Wear
[[British national grid reference system|OS grid reference]]  {{gbmaprim|NZ256617|NZ256617}} | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|54.950|-1.602|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | established = | dissolved = | location = [[Gateshead]], [[County Durham]], England | type = | collection = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = }} The '''Shipley Art Gallery''' is an art gallery in [[Gateshead]], [[Tyne and Wear]], [[England]], located at the south end of Prince Consort Road. It has a Designated Collection of national importance.{{Cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/ne000029|title=Shipley Art Gallery|last=|first=|date=|website=Culture24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 February 2018}} ==Origins== The Shipley Art Gallery opened to the public in 1917. This was made possible by a bequest from wealthy local solicitor and art collector, Joseph Ainsley Davidson Shipley (1822–1909). Shipley was a rather enigmatic person about whom little is known. He was born in Gateshead, near High Street. He was a solicitor in the [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] firm of Hoyle, Shipley and Hoyle. From 1884 until his death, he leased [[Saltwell Park]] House, now known as Saltwell Towers. Shipley’s main passion was art and collecting paintings. He bought his first painting when he was sixteen and by the time he died he had amassed a collection of some 2,500 paintings. On his death, Shipley left £30,000 and all his pictures to the City of Newcastle, which was to build a new gallery to house the collection. This was to be known as "The Shipley Bequest". His will specifically excluded the [[Laing Art Gallery]] in Newcastle from benefiting from the bequest, and this clause became the subject of much public discussion, and eventually led to Newcastle's rejection of the bequest. It was only following this that Gateshead Municipal Council was offered the collection. As it was impossible to house all of the paintings, 359 of the pictures recommended by the executors of Shipley's will were selected. A further group was then added by the Gateshead Committee, bringing the total to 504.{{Cite news|url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/theatre-news/gallery-opens-doors-reveal-delights-1630079|title=Gallery opens the doors to reveal its delights|last=|first=|date=8 September 2004|work=Evening Chronicle|access-date=3 May 2018}} In 1914, after the sale of the remaining paintings, work began on the new art gallery. The building, which was designed by Arthur Stockwell, M.S.A. of Newcastle, opened on 29 November 1917. The stone entrance portico is ''[[distyle in antis]]'' – four Corinthian-style stone columns flanked by solid pilasters. These are surmounted by two sculptured figures, one representing the Arts and the other Industry and Learning, by [[William Birnie Rhind|W. Birnie Rhind]], [[Royal Scottish Academy|R.S.A]]. of [[Edinburgh]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xD9IAQAAIAAJ|title=Newcastle and Gateshead|publisher=Yale University Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-300-12664-8|page=263}} Pevsner described the art gallery as a "bold arrangement of a brick central block and lower wings containing galleries".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjHcM_LXhjEC|title=County Durham|author1=Nikolaus Pevsner|author2=Elizabeth Williamson|publisher=Yale University Press|year=1983|isbn=978-0-300-09599-9|page=286}} The building was designated as [[Listed building#Categories of listed building|Grade II listed]] in 1982.{{National Heritage List for England|num=1248566|desc=Shipley Art Gallery|access-date=13 February 2018}} ==Present gallery== The original 504 paintings represented all the main European schools from the sixteenth to the nineteenth centuries. Since 1917, the collection has been added to, and now comprises some 10,000 items. William C. Irving's painting, "Blaydon Races" captures the spirit of the traditional [[Blaydon Races]], and takes pride of place at the gallery. The gallery also holds a strong collection of 16th and 17th century Dutch and Flemish paintings, as well as 19th century British works, watercolours, prints, drawings and sculpture.{{Cite web|url=https://shipleyartgallery.org.uk/collections/our-collections|title=Our collections|last=|first=|date=|website=Shipley Art Gallery|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 February 2018}} Since 1977 the gallery has become established as a national centre for contemporary craftwork. It has built up one of the best collections outside London, which includes ceramics, wood, metal, glass, textiles and furniture.{{Cite web|url=https://shipleyartgallery.org.uk/about-us/about-the-shipley|title=About the Shipley|last=|first=|date=|website=Shipley Art Gallery|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 February 2018}} In 2008, the Shipley opened its ''Designs for Life'' gallery which showcases the gallery's collections of contemporary craft and design. The Gallery also hosts a varied programme of temporary exhibitions and has a strong partnership with the [[V&A Museum]] in London. The Shipley Art Gallery is managed by [[Tyne & Wear Archives & Museums]] on behalf of [[Gateshead Council]]. ==External links== * {{commonscat-inline|Shipley Art Gallery}} * {{official website|https://shipleyartgallery.org.uk/}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Tyne & Wear Archives & Museums]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Tyne and Wear]] [[Category:Gateshead]] [[Category:Contemporary crafts museums]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1917]] [[Category:1917 establishments in England]]

A '''sub-field dictionary''' is a [[specialized dictionary]] that has been designed and compiled to cover the terms of one (or possibly more) sub-fields of a particular subject field. It is therefore a sub-division of the class of dictionary called a [[single-field dictionary]]. Sub-field dictionaries should be contrasted with multi-field dictionaries and single-field dictionaries.
The typology consisting of these three dictionaries is important for a number of reasons. First of all a sub-field dictionary is an example of a very specialized dictionary in that it covers only a limited part of one single subject field. Examples of sub-field dictionaries are a dictionary of contract law (as opposed to the single-field dictionary of law) and a dictionary of fusion welding (as opposed to a dictionary of welding), or a dictionary of ethical philosophy (as opposed to a dictionary of philosophy).
The main advantage of sub-field dictionaries is that they can easily be [[maximizing dictionary|maximizing dictionaries]], i.e. deep rather than broad, attempting to cover as many terms of the sub-field as possible without expanding into several volumes. Consequently, sub-field dictionaries are ideal for extensive coverage of the linguistic and extra-linguistic aspects within a particular subject field.
Secondly, if the lexicographers intend to make a bilingual, maximizing sub-field dictionary they will not run into the same problems with the space available for presenting the large amount of data that has to be included in the dictionary, cf. a [[multi-field dictionary]].
Consequently, the best coverage of linguistic and extra-linguistic aspects within the subject field covered by a dictionary will be found in a sub-field dictionary. The best coverage of a subject field will then be to compile a number of sub-field dictionaries that together cover the entire subject.
==Further reading== *Sandro Nielsen: "Contrastive Description of Dictionaries Covering LSP Communication". In: Fachsprache/International Journal of LSP 3-4/1990, 129–136.
{{Lexicography}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sub-Field Dictionary}} [[Category:Dictionaries by type]]

revision.text:
{{About|technical standards||Standards (disambiguation){{!}}Standard}} {{refimprove|date=February 2014}}
A '''technical standard''' is an established [[norm (social)|norm]] or [[requirement]] in regard to technical [[system]]s. It is usually a formal document that establishes uniform engineering or technical criteria, methods, processes, and practices. In contrast, a custom, [[Convention (norm)|convention]], company product, corporate standard, and so forth that becomes generally accepted and dominant is often called a [[de facto standard|''de facto'' standard]].
A technical standard may be developed privately or unilaterally, for example by a corporation, regulatory body, military, etc. Standards can also be developed by groups such as trade unions and trade associations. [[Standards organizations]] often have more diverse input and usually develop voluntary standards: these might become mandatory if adopted by a government (i.e., through [[legislation]]), business contract, etc.
The [[standardization]] process may be by edict or may involve the formal consensus<ref>Example of [https://archive.is/20120913132347/http://www.tappi.org/s_tappi/doc.asp?CID=107&DID=551843 TAPPI standards development regulations]</ref> of technical experts.
==Types== The primary types of technical standards are: * A ''standard [[specification]]'' is an explicit set of requirements for an item, material, component, system or service. It is often used to formalize the technical aspects of a procurement agreement or [[contract]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Standard Specifications|url=http://www.oregon.gov/odot/hwy/specs/pages/standard_specifications.aspx|website=Oregon.gov|publisher=Oregon.gov|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> For example, there may be a specification for a turbine blade for a jet engine that defines the exact material and performance requirements. * A ''standard [[test method]]'' describes a definitive procedure that produces a test result. It may involve making a careful personal observation or conducting a highly technical measurement. For example, a [[physical property]] of a material is often affected by the precise method of testing: any reference to the property should therefore reference the test method used. * A ''standard practice'' or procedure gives a set of instructions for performing operations or functions. For example, there are detailed [[standard operating procedure]]s for operation of a nuclear power plant.<ref>{{cite web|title=Operational Limits and Conditions and Operating Procedures for Nuclear Power Plants Safety Guide|url=http://www-pub.iaea.org/books/IAEABooks/6064/Operational-Limits-and-Conditions-and-Operating-Procedures-for-Nuclear-Power-Plants-Safety-Guide|website=International Atomic Energy Association|publisher=IAEA|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * A ''standard guide'' is general information or options that do not require a specific course of action. * A ''standard [[definition]]'' is formally established terminology. * ''Standard [[units of measurement|units]]'', in [[physics]] and [[applied mathematics]], are commonly accepted measurements of physical quantities.
==Availability== Technical standards may exist as: * Public documents on the [[internet]], public library, etc. (Some technical standards may be found at a major central library or at the library of a good technical university) * Published documents available for purchase * Private documents owned by an organization or corporation, used and circulated as the owner determines necessary or useful * Documents publicly available under [[intellectual property]] ([[copyright]], etc.)<ref>Example: [http://www.sae.org/about/copyright/ SAE International copyright policy]</ref> * Closed or controlled documents that contain [[trade secret]]s or [[classified information]]
==Geographic levels== When a geographically defined community must solve a community-wide [[coordination problem]], it can adopt an existing standard or produce a new one. The main geographic levels are: * ''National standard'': by [[Standards organizations#National_standards_organizations|National standards organizations]]. For example, [[Telecommunications Industry Association]] standards. * ''Regional standard'': see standards of the [[Standards organizations#Regional_standards_organizations|Regional standards organizations]]. For example, [[European Committee for Standardization|CEN]] standards. * ''[[International standard]]'': see [[Standards organizations#International_standards_organizations|International standards organizations]] Example, [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] and [[ASTM International]].
National/Regional/International standards is one way of overcoming technical barriers in inter-local or inter-regional commerce caused by differences among technical regulations and standards developed independently and separately by each local, local [[standards organisation]], or local company. Technical barriers arise when different groups come together, each with a large user base, doing some well established thing that between them is mutually incompatible. Establishing national/regional/international standards is one way of preventing or overcoming this problem.
==Usage== The existence of a published standard does not imply that it is always useful or correct. For example, if an item complies with a certain standard, there is not necessarily assurance that it is fit for any particular use. The people who use the item or service (engineers, trade unions, etc.) or specify it (building codes, government, industry, etc.) have the responsibility to consider the available standards, specify the correct one, enforce compliance, and use the item correctly. [[Validation and verification|Validation]] of suitability is necessary.
Standards often get reviewed, revised and updated on a regular basis. It is critical that the most current version of a published standard be used or referenced. The originator or standard writing body often has the current versions listed on its web site.
In [[social sciences]], including [[economics]], a standard is useful if it is a solution to a [[coordination problem]]: it emerges from situations in which all parties realize mutual gains, but only by making mutually consistent decisions. '''Examples''': {| class="wikitable" !Parties !Mutual gains !Problem !Solution |- |[[Secondary sector of the economy|Mechanical industry]] companies |[[Supply chain|Suppliers]] interchange, stock gains, etc. |[[Screw#Thread_standards|Screw thread]] compatibility |[[Screw_thread#Standardization|Screw thread standard specifications]] |- |[[Pharmaceutical industry]] and [[Medic|medic community]] |Enable [[Therapy|medical prescriptions]], suppliers interchange, etc. |[[Pharmaceutical drug|Drug]] uniformity |[[Specification#Food_and_drug_specifications|Drug standard specifications]] |}
==See also== * [[List of computer standards]] * [[Software standard]] * [[List of technical standard organisations]] * [[Specification (technical standard)]] * [[Standard (metrology)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Standards]] [[Category:Documents]] [[Category:Technical communication]] [[Category:Technical specifications]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = The Craft of Research | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Craft of Research.jpg | caption = | authors = [[Wayne C. Booth]], [[Gregory G. Colomb]], [[Joseph M. Williams]], Joseph Bizup, and William T. Fitzgerald | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[University of Chicago Press]] | pub_date = October 2016 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print | pages = 336 | isbn = 978-0226239736 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Craft of Research''''' is a book by [[Wayne C. Booth]], [[Gregory G. Colomb]], [[Joseph M. Williams]], Joseph Bizup, and William T. Fitzgerald.{{ref|authors}} The work is published by the [[University of Chicago Press]].
The book aims to provide a basic overview of how to research, from the process of selecting a topic and gathering sources to the process of writing results. The book has become a standard text in college composition classes and is now in its fourth edition.
The first edition of ''The Craft of Research'' was a winner of the 1995-1996 Critics' Choice Award.{{ref|amazon_description}}
Material from ''The Craft of Research'' has also been adapted to form the first part of [[Kate L. Turabian]]'s ''[[A Manual for Writers of Research Papers, Theses, and Dissertations]]''.
==Book Structure== Below is the structure of the work, as outlined in the fourth edition.
===Preface: The Aims of This Edition===
===I. Research, Researchers, and Readers=== *Thinking in Print: The Uses of Research, Public and Private *Connecting with Your Reader: Creating a Role for Yourself and Your Readers
===II. Asking Questions, Finding Answers=== *From Topics to Questions *From Questions to Problems *From Problems to Sources *Engaging Sources
===III. Making an Argument=== *Making Good Arguments: An Overview *Making Claims *Assembling Reasons and Evidence *Acknowledgments and Responses *Warrants
===IV. Writing Your Argument=== *Planning and Drafting *Organizing Your Argument *Incorporating Sources *Communicating Evidence Visually *Introductions and Conclusions *Revising Style: Telling Your Story Clearly
===V. Some Last Considerations=== *The Ethics of Research *A Postscript for Teachers *Appendix: Bibliographical Resources
== Editions ==
{| class="wikitable" |+Editions of '''''The Craft of Research''''' !Edition !Year !ISBN !In Print? |- |First |1995 |{{ISBN|978-0226065847}} |No |- |Second |2003 |{{ISBN|978-0226065670}} |No |- |Third |2008 |{{ISBN|978-0226065656}} (Cloth) {{ISBN|978-0226065663}} (Paperback) |Yes |- |Fourth |2016 |{{ISBN|978-0226239736}} |Yes |}
==Translations==
Arabic, Mandarin, Cantonese, [http://www.yes24.com/Goods/FTGoodsView.aspx?goodsNo=153967&CategoryNumber=001 Korean], [http://www.siciliano.com.br/livro.asp?orn=LCAT&Tipo=2&ID=444316 Portuguese], [http://www.ozon.ru/context/detail/id/1893446/ Russian], [http://www.agapea.com/Como-convertirse-en-un-habil-investigador-n76004i.htm Spanish], and [http://www.adlibris.se/product.aspx?isbn=9144032277&r=1 Swedish].
== Notes == :1.{{note|authors}}Joseph Bizup and William T. Fitzgerald became contributing authors with the fourth edition of ''The Craft of Research''.
:2.{{note|amazon_description}} [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0226065847 The Craft of Research (Chicago Guides to Writing, Editing, and Publishing) 1st Edition] listed on Amazon.com
== External links ==
*[https://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/C/bo23521678.html ''The Craft of Research'', Fourth Edition] at the University of Chicago Press *[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/065685in.html Interview with the authors] *[http://guides.library.yale.edu/eng114 Yale Library Research Guide]
